messages.text:
Just made an Apple Pie! Store bought crust like a true chef.
But - here's my smoothie recipe:
Add 1 banana to blender and 1/4th a bag of spinach with ~3/4cup of oat milk. Blend. Add frozen blueberries until thick and purple/black. Blend. There you now have like 1/100th your daily value of vegetables.

elements.text:

messages.text:
I made frozen yogurt last night.
I mean I have frozen yogurt before and it's like OK. But it is like a hard block. Not the soft  ice creamy stuff you get from a froyo shop.
But I got it to work and it is ridiculously simple.
Sugar disrupts the ice formation preventing it becoming a single blocky.
By mass it is like 1 unit of sugar to 4 units of yogurt (I guess less if yogurt is already sweetened).
Beat with electric mixer.
Freeze.

messages.text: New hot sauce recipe: 10-12 habernero peppers. Take the seeds out of half unless you like pain. 4 large dried guajilla peppers (can toast them lightly in a pan for a few seconds for better flavor but either way its good). 3/4 cup vinegar. Half of a small onion. 1 tbsp minced garlic. Blend. Cook on low heat for 10min (caution fumes). Blend again and add vinegar/water as needed to make a pastey liquid.

elements.text: New hot sauce recipe: 10-12 habernero peppers. Take the seeds out of half unless you like pain. 4 large dried guajilla peppers (can toast them lightly in a pan for a few seconds for better flavor but either way its good). 3/4 cup vinegar. Half of a small onion. 1 tbsp minced garlic. Blend. Cook on low heat for 10min (caution fumes). Blend again and add vinegar/water as needed to make a pastey liquid.

messages.text: <@U6S2GUM43> has joined the channel

Actually making some Kraut today. It's dead simple (though can get wild):

• 1 large red or green cabbage, cut into thin strips
• weigh the cabbage, get 2-3% by mass salt (so if your cabbage is 500g, you want 10-15g salt). I usually err on the higher end
• Thuroughly massage the salt into the cabbage,  pack it tightly into a jar. There should be water coming out
• Make sure the cabbage stays under the liquid using a weight (ziplock bag with water in it works fine)
• Wait 1-4 weeks, tasting frequently
That's it. I usually also add shallots and a pepper or two (usually just the skins, I like habenero or fresno best). Traditional German kraut also has caraway seeds, though I usually skip those myself.

And there's a billion other variations from other regions with different veggies. The basic recipe is Vegetable + salt + time = delicious.

elements.text: Actually making some Kraut today. It's dead simple (though can get wild):
1 large red or green cabbage, cut into thin strips
weigh the cabbage, get 2-3% by mass salt (so if your cabbage is 500g, you want 10-15g salt). I usually err on the higher end
Thuroughly massage the salt into the cabbage,  pack it tightly into a jar. There should be water coming out
Make sure the cabbage stays under the liquid using a weight (ziplock bag with water in it works fine)
Wait 1-4 weeks, tasting frequently

That's it. I usually also add shallots and a pepper or two (usually just the skins, I like habenero or fresno best). Traditional German kraut also has caraway seeds, though I usually skip those myself.

And there's a billion other variations from other regions with different veggies. The basic recipe is Vegetable + salt + time = delicious.

attachments.title: Tocosh
attachments.text:
Tocosh (also known as togosh) is a traditional Quechua food prepared from fermented potato pulp (maize is less common). It is often prepared for celebration events and has a strong odor and flavor. Tocosh can be used as a natural antibiotic because penicillin is produced during the fermentation process. Medicinally it is used for the common cold, gastric ulcers, pneumonia, and altitude sickness among others. The Incas believed it was a gift from Inti for preservation of the body.
The fermentation process of creating tocosh was discovered by the Incas (or possibly one of the many tribes in their empire). Fermentation is achieved by placing either potato pulp or maize in a mesh bag of grass, covered with stones, and left undisturbed for six to twelve months within a pool of water where there is a current (the pool usually found naturally or dug on the banks of a stream). The current flows through the stones to wash away bacteria during fermentation. Once fermentation has occurred, the tocosh is dried in the sun and stored for future use.
The most common preparation in the Huánuco region of Peru is to make a mazamorra or jelly-like dessert.

elements.text: Case in point:
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tocosh
